Front: AWS Regions are clusters of data centers in geographic locations. Each region has multiple Availability Zones (usually 3-6), which are isolated data centers with redundant power, networking, and connectivity. Regions are completely isolated from each other for fault tolerance.
Back: What is an AWS Region and how many Availability Zones does it typically contain?

Front: Choose AWS regions based on: compliance/data governance requirements, proximity to customers (latency), service availability, and pricing (varies by region). Data never leaves a region without explicit permission.
Back: What factors should you consider when choosing an AWS region for your application?

Front: AWS Global services operate across all regions: IAM, Route 53, CloudFront, WAF. Most AWS services are Region-scoped: EC2, Elastic Beanstalk, Lambda, and must be explicitly replicated across regions.
Back: Which AWS services are Global (work across all regions) versus Region-scoped?

Front: The AWS Free Tier allows new customers to use AWS services at no charge within certain limits. It includes: Always Free (S3, Lambda, DynamoDB), 12 Months Free (EC2, RDS), and Trials (various services). Some services are free forever, others for 12 months.
Back: What is the AWS Free Tier and what types of free offerings does it include?

Front: The AWS Management Console is a web-based GUI for managing AWS resources. Use it for: visual resource management, one-time tasks, learning AWS. Use AWS CLI for: automation, scripting, programmatic access, CI/CD pipelines.
Back: When should you use the AWS Management Console versus the AWS CLI?

Front: IAM (Identity and Access Management) is a global service that manages access to AWS resources. Core components: Users (people/apps), Groups (collections of users), Roles (temporary permissions), Policies (JSON permission documents).
Back: What is IAM and what are its core components?

Front: Amazon S3 is object storage for any amount of data. Key features: 99.999999999% (11 nines) durability, unlimited storage, versioning, lifecycle policies. Primary use cases: backup, static website hosting, data lakes, content distribution.
Back: What is Amazon S3 and what are its key durability characteristics and primary use cases?

Front: Amazon EC2 provides resizable compute capacity (virtual servers) in the cloud. Benefits: pay only for compute time, scalable on-demand, no upfront costs, multiple instance types and operating systems.
Back: What is Amazon EC2 and what are its key benefits compared to on-premises servers?

Front: AWS Lambda is a serverless compute service that runs code in response to events. Benefits: no server management, automatic scaling, pay per request/compute time, integrated with AWS services. Use cases: event-driven apps, microservices, data processing.
Back: What is AWS Lambda and what are its primary benefits and use cases?

Front: Amazon RDS is a managed relational database service supporting MySQL, PostgreSQL, MariaDB, Oracle, SQL Server, and Aurora. Benefits: automated backups, patching, monitoring, scaling, high availability with Multi-AZ deployments.
Back: What databases does Amazon RDS support and what are its key management benefits?

Front: AWS VPC (Virtual Private Cloud) is a logically isolated network where you launch AWS resources. Features: complete control over IP ranges, subnets, route tables, network gateways. Enables private networking and network segmentation for security.
Back: What is an AWS VPC and what level of network control does it provide?

Front: AWS CloudFormation enables Infrastructure as Code (IaC). You define resources in JSON/YAML templates, and CloudFormation provisions and manages them. Benefits: reproducible infrastructure, version control, automated deployments, rollback capability.
Back: What is AWS CloudFormation and how does it enable Infrastructure as Code?

Front: AWS Elastic Beanstalk is a Platform as a Service (PaaS) that handles deployment, capacity provisioning, load balancing, auto-scaling, and application health monitoring. You just upload code. Best for: web applications, quick deployments, minimal infrastructure management.
Back: What is AWS Elastic Beanstalk and what types of applications benefit most from it?

Front: AWS Auto Scaling automatically adjusts capacity to maintain performance at the lowest cost. It works with EC2, ECS, DynamoDB, and Aurora. Triggers include: CloudWatch metrics (CPU, network, custom), scheduled scaling, and predictive scaling.
Back: What services work with AWS Auto Scaling and what can trigger scaling events?

Front: Amazon CloudWatch is a monitoring and observability service. Features: metrics (performance data), logs (application logs), alarms (notifications/actions), dashboards (visualization). It monitors AWS resources and applications in real-time.
Back: What are the key features of Amazon CloudWatch for monitoring AWS resources?

Front: Amazon Route 53 is a scalable DNS web service. Functions: domain registration, DNS routing, health checks, traffic management. Routing policies: Simple, Weighted, Latency-based, Failover, Geolocation, Multi-value.
Back: What is Amazon Route 53 and what routing policies does it support?

Front: Security Groups are virtual firewalls for EC2 instances. Key characteristics: stateful (allow inbound automatically allows outbound response), operate at instance level, default deny all inbound, allow all outbound. Rules control traffic by protocol, port, and source/destination.
Back: What are Security Groups and what are their key characteristics regarding traffic rules?

Front: AWS offers three load balancer types: Application Load Balancer (ALB) for HTTP/HTTPS Layer 7, Network Load Balancer (NLB) for TCP/UDP Layer 4 high performance, Classic Load Balancer (CLB) legacy. ALB supports content-based routing, SSL termination, and container targets.
Back: What are the three types of Elastic Load Balancers in AWS and when should each be used?

Front: Auto Scaling Groups ensure the correct number of EC2 instances are running. They work with ELB to: distribute traffic across healthy instances, replace unhealthy instances, scale based on demand, maintain minimum/maximum/desired capacity.
Back: How do Auto Scaling Groups work with Elastic Load Balancing to provide high availability?

Front: AWS Trusted Advisor provides real-time best practice recommendations in: Cost Optimization, Security, Performance, Fault Tolerance. Full access requires Business or Enterprise support plans. Basic plan shows limited checks.
Back: What recommendations does AWS Trusted Advisor provide and which support plans include full access?

Front: AWS CloudTrail records AWS API calls for governance, compliance, and auditing. It logs: who made the call, what service was called, when it happened, where from (IP), result. Logs are stored in S3 buckets. Essential for security auditing and compliance.
Back: What does AWS CloudTrail log and how does it help with security auditing and compliance?

Front: AWS Organizations centralizes management of multiple AWS accounts. Benefits: consolidated billing, account-wide policies via Service Control Policies (SCPs), easier account creation and management, shared payment methods. Useful for enterprises managing multiple accounts.
Back: What are the key benefits of using AWS Organizations for managing multiple AWS accounts?

Front: The AWS Well-Architected Framework has five pillars: Operational Excellence (run/monitor systems), Security (protect information), Reliability (recover from failures), Performance Efficiency (use resources efficiently), Cost Optimization (avoid unnecessary costs).
Back: What are the five pillars of the AWS Well-Architected Framework?

Front: The AWS Shared Responsibility Model divides security responsibilities: AWS manages security OF the cloud (infrastructure, hardware, software, networking, facilities). Customer manages security IN the cloud (data, configurations, access management, encryption, network traffic).
Back: How does the AWS Shared Responsibility Model divide security responsibilities between AWS and customers?

Front: AWS Support Plans: Basic (free) - account/billing support, documentation; Developer ($29/month) - business hours email support; Business ($100/month) - 24/7 phone/email/chat, technical account manager, Infrastructure Event Management; Enterprise (custom) - all Business features plus dedicated TAM, support API, better SLA.
Back: What are the different AWS Support Plans and what features differentiate them?

Front: AWS Marketplace is a digital catalog with thousands of third-party software solutions. Benefits: quick deployment (click to launch), billing through AWS account, tested on AWS infrastructure, categories: AMIs, SaaS, container images, data products.
Back: What is AWS Marketplace and what are its primary benefits?

Front: AWS Pricing Models: On-Demand (pay as you go, no commitment), Reserved Instances (1-3 year commitment, up to 75% discount), Savings Plans (flexible, compute discount), Spot Instances (bid for unused capacity, up to 90% discount, can be interrupted).
Back: What are the main AWS pricing models and what are their key characteristics?

Front: IAM Roles provide temporary credentials to AWS services or users without storing long-term access keys. Benefits: automatic credential rotation, no key management, fine-grained permissions, used by EC2 instances, Lambda functions, and cross-account access. More secure than access keys.
Back: What are the advantages of using IAM Roles instead of access keys for AWS service permissions?

Front: AWS Resource Tagging allows metadata labels on resources. Benefits: cost allocation (track spending by project/department), automation (scripts can filter by tags), resource organization, compliance tracking. Tags are key-value pairs (e.g., Environment:Production, Project:WebApp).
Back: How does AWS resource tagging help with cost tracking and resource management?

Front: AWS Service Limits (quotas) protect you from unexpected costs and ensure fair resource allocation. Default limits vary by service (e.g., EC2 instance limits, S3 bucket limits). Check limits in Service Quotas console, request increases via Support Center. Limits exist per region per account.
Back: How can you check AWS service limits and why do these limits exist?
